name: Hemingway - the Undefeated
body:
Manuel Garcia climbed the stairs to Don
Miguel Retanaâs office. He set down his suitcase
and knocked on the door. There was no
answer. Manuel, standing in the hallway, felt
there was some one in the room. He felt it
through the door.
âRetana,â he said, listening.
There was no answer.
Heâs there, all right, Manuel thought.
âRetana,â he said and banged the door.
âWhoâs there?â said some one in the office.
âMe, Manolo,â Manuel said.
âWhat do you want?â asked the voice.
âI want to work,â Manuel said.
Something in the door clicked several times
and it swung open. Manuel went in, carrying
his suitcase.
A little man sat behind a desk at the far side
of the room. Over his head was a bullâs head,
stuffed by a Madrid taxidermist; on the walls
were framed photographs and bull-fight posters.
The little man sat looking at Manuel.
âI thought theyâd killed you,â he said.
Manuel knocked with his knuckles on the
desk. The little man sat looking at him across
the desk.
âHow many corridas you had this year?â
Retana asked.
âOne,â he answered.
âJust that one?â the little man asked.
âThatâs all.â
âI read about it in the papers,â Retana said.
He leaned back in the chair and looked at Manuel.
Manuel looked up at the stuffed bull. He
had seen it often before. He felt a certain
family interest in it. It had killed his brother,
the promising one, about nine years ago. Manuel
remembered the day. There was a brass
plate on the oak shield the bullâs head was
mounted on. Manuel could not read it, but
he imagined it was in memory of his brother.
Well, he had been a good kid.
The plate said: âThe Bull âMariposaâ of the
Duke of Veragua, which accepted 9 varas for 7
caballos, and caused the death of Antonio Garcia,
Novillero, April 27, 1909.â
Retana saw him looking at the stuffed bullâs
head.
âThe lot the Duke sent me for Sunday will
make a scandal,â he said. âTheyâre all bad in
the legs. What do they say about them at the
CafÃ©?â
âI donât know,â Manuel said. âI just got
in.â
âYes,â Retana said. âYou still have your
bag.â
He looked at Manuel, leaning back behind
the big desk.
âSit down,â he said. âTake off your cap.â
Manuel sat down; his cap off, his face was
changed. He looked pale, and his coleta pinned
forward on his head, so that it would not show
under the cap, gave him a strange look.
âYou donât look well,â Retana said.
âI just got out of the hospital,â Manuel
said.
âI heard theyâd cut your leg off,â Retana
said.
âNo,â said Manuel. âIt got all right.â
Retana leaned forward across the desk and
pushed a wooden box of cigarettes toward Manuel.
âHave a cigarette,â he said.
âThanks.â
Manuel lit it.
âSmoke?â he said, offering the match to
Retana.
âNo,â Retana waved his hand, âI never
smoke.â
Retana watched him smoking.
âWhy donât you get a job and go to work?â
he said.
âI donât want to work,â Manuel said. âI
am a bull-fighter.â
âThere arenât any bull-fighters any more,â
Retana said.
âIâm a bull-fighter,â Manuel said.
âYes, while youâre in there,â Retana said.
Manuel laughed.
Retana sat, saying nothing and looking at
Manuel.
âIâll put you in a nocturnal if you want,â
Retana offered.
âWhen?â Manuel asked.
âTo-morrow night.â
âI donât like to substitute for anybody,â Manuel
said. That was the way they all got killed.
That was the way Salvador got killed. He
tapped with his knuckles on the table.
âItâs all Iâve got,â Retana said.
âWhy donât you put me on next week?â
Manuel suggested.
âYou wouldnât draw,â Retana said. âAll
they want is Litri and Rubito and La Torre.
Those kids are good.â
âTheyâd come to see me get it,â Manuel said,
hopefully.
âNo, they wouldnât. They donât know who
you are any more.â
âIâve got a lot of stuff,â Manuel said.
âIâm offering to put you on to-morrow
night,â Retana said. âYou can work with
young Hernandez and kill two novillos after
the Chariots.â
âWhose novillos?â Manuel asked.
âI donât know. Whatever stuff theyâve got
in the corrals. What the veterinaries wonât
pass in the daytime.â
âI donât like to substitute,â Manuel said.
âYou can take it or leave it,â Retana said.
He leaned forward over the papers. He was
no longer interested. The appeal that Manuel
had made to him for a moment when he
thought of the old days was gone. He would
like to get him to substitute for Larita because
he could get him cheaply. He could get others
cheaply too. He would like to help him though.
Still he had given him the chance. It was up
to him.
âHow much do I get?â Manuel asked. He
was still playing with the idea of refusing. But
he knew he could not refuse.
âTwo hundred and fifty pesetas,â Retana
said. He had thought of five hundred, but
when he opened his mouth it said two hundred
and fifty.
âYou pay Villalta seven thousand,â Manuel
said.
âYouâre not Villalta,â Retana said.
âI know it,â Manuel said.
âHe draws it, Manolo,â Retana said in explanation.
âSure,â said Manuel. He stood up. âGive
me three hundred, Retana.â
âAll right,â Retana agreed. He reached in
the drawer for a paper.
âCan I have fifty now?â Manuel asked.
âSure,â said Retana. He took a fifty peseta
note out of his pocket-book and laid it, spread
out flat, on the table.
Manuel picked it up and put it in his pocket.
âWhat about a cuadrilla?â he asked.
âThereâs the boys that always work for me
nights,â Retana said. âTheyâre all right.â
âHow about picadors?â Manuel asked.
âTheyâre not much,â Retana admitted.
âIâve got to have one good pic,â Manuel said.
âGet him then,â Retana said. âGo and get
him.â
âNot out of this,â Manuel said. âIâm not
paying for any cuadrilla out of sixty duros.â
Retana said nothing but looked at Manuel
across the big desk.
âYou know Iâve got to have one good pic,â
Manuel said.
Retana said nothing but looked at Manuel
from a long way off.
âIt isnât right,â Manuel said.
Retana was still considering him, leaning
back in his chair, considering him from a long
way away.
âThereâre the regular pics,â he offered.
âI know,â Manuel said. âI know your regular
pics.â
Retana did not smile. Manuel knew it was
over.
âAll I want is an even break,â Manuel said
reasoningly. âWhen I go out there I want to
be able to call my shots on the bull. It only
takes one good picador.â
He was talking to a man who was no longer
listening.
âIf you want something extra,â Retana said,
âgo and get it. There will be a regular cuadrilla
out there. Bring as many of your own
pics as you want. The charlotada is over by
10.30.â
âAll right,â Manuel said. âIf thatâs the way
you feel about it.â
âThatâs the way,â Retana said.
âIâll see you to-morrow night,â Manuel said.
âIâll be out there,â Retana said.
Manuel picked up his suitcase and went out.
âShut the door,â Retana called.
Manuel looked back. Retana was sitting forward
looking at some papers. Manuel pulled
the door tight until it clicked.
He went down the stairs and out of the door
into the hot brightness of the street. It was
very hot in the street and the light on the white
buildings was sudden and hard on his eyes. He
walked down the shady side of the steep street
toward the Puerta del Sol. The shade felt solid
and cool as running water. The heat came suddenly
as he crossed the intersecting streets.
Manuel saw no one he knew in all the people he
passed.
Just before the Puerta del Sol he turned into
a cafÃ©.
It was quiet in the cafÃ©. There were a few
men sitting at tables against the wall. At one
table four men played cards. Most of the men
sat against the wall smoking, empty coffee-cups
and liqueur-glasses before them on the tables.
Manuel went through the long room to a small
room in back. A man sat at a table in the corner
asleep. Manuel sat down at one of the
tables.
A waiter came in and stood beside Manuelâs
table.
âHave you seen Zurito?â Manuel asked him.
âHe was in before lunch,â the waiter answered.
âHe wonât be back before five oâclock.â
âBring me some coffee and milk and a shot
of the ordinary,â Manuel said.
The waiter came back into the room carrying
a tray with a big coffee-glass and a liqueur-glass
on it. In his left hand he held a bottle of
brandy. He swung these down to the table
and a boy who had followed him poured coffee
and milk into the glass from two shiny, spouted
pots with long handles.
Manuel took off his cap and the waiter noticed
his pigtail pinned forward on his head.
He winked at the coffee-boy as he poured out
the brandy into the little glass beside Manuelâs
coffee. The coffee-boy looked at Manuelâs pale
face curiously.
âYou fighting here?â asked the waiter, corking
up the bottle.
âYes,â Manuel said. âTo-morrow.â
The waiter stood there, holding the bottle on
one hip.
âYou in the Charlie Chaplins?â he asked.
The coffee-boy looked away, embarrassed.
âNo. In the ordinary.â
âI thought they were going to have Chaves
and Hernandez,â the waiter said.
âNo. Me and another.â
âWho? Chaves or Hernandez?â
âHernandez, I think.â
âWhatâs the matter with Chaves?â
âHe got hurt.â
âWhere did you hear that?â
âRetana.â
âHey, Looie,â the waiter called to the next
room, âChaves got cogida.â
Manuel had taken the wrapper off the lumps
of sugar and dropped them into his coffee. He
stirred it and drank it down, sweet, hot, and
warming in his empty stomach. He drank off
the brandy.
âGive me another shot of that,â he said to
the waiter.
The waiter uncorked the bottle and poured
the glass full, slopping another drink into the
saucer. Another waiter had come up in front of
the table. The coffee-boy was gone.
âIs Chaves hurt bad?â the second waiter
asked Manuel.
âI donât know,â Manuel said, âRetana didnât
say.â
âA hell of a lot he cares,â the tall waiter said.
Manuel had not seen him before. He must
have just come up.
âIf you stand in with Retana in this town,
youâre a made man,â the tall waiter said. âIf
you arenât in with him, you might just as well
go out and shoot yourself.â
âYou said it,â the other waiter who had come
in said. âYou said it then.â
âYouâre right I said it,â said the tall waiter.
âI know what Iâm talking about when I talk
about that bird.â
âLook what heâs done for Villalta,â the first
waiter said.
âAnd that ainât all,â the tall waiter said.
âLook what heâs done for Marcial Lalanda.
Look what heâs done for Nacional.â
âYou said it, kid,â agreed the short waiter.
Manuel looked at them, standing talking in
front of his table. He had drunk his second
brandy. They had forgotten about him. They
were not interested in him.
âLook at that bunch of camels,â the tall
waiter went on. âDid you ever see this Nacional
II?â
âI seen him last Sunday didnât I?â the original
waiter said.
âHeâs a giraffe,â the short waiter said.
âWhat did I tell you?â the tall waiter said.
âThose are Retanaâs boys.â
âSay, give me another shot of that,â Manuel
said. He had poured the brandy the waiter had
slopped over in the saucer into his glass and
drank it while they were talking.
The original waiter poured his glass full
mechanically, and the three of them went out
of the room talking.
In the far corner the man was still asleep,
snoring slightly on the intaking breath, his head
back against the wall.
Manuel drank his brandy. He felt sleepy
himself. It was too hot to go out into the town.
Besides there was nothing to do. He wanted
to see Zurito. He would go to sleep while he
waited. He kicked his suitcase under the table
to be sure it was there. Perhaps it would be
better to put it back under the seat, against the
wall. He leaned down and shoved it under.
Then he leaned forward on the table and went
to sleep.
When he woke there was some one sitting
across the table from him. It was a big man
with a heavy brown face like an Indian. He
had been sitting there some time. He had
waved the waiter away and sat reading the
paper and occasionally looking down at Manuel,
asleep, his head on the table. He read the paper
laboriously, forming the words with his lips as
he read. When it tired him he looked at Manuel.
He sat heavily in the chair, his black Cordoba
hat tipped forward.
Manuel sat up and looked at him.
âHello, Zurito,â he said.
âHello, kid,â the big man said.
âIâve been asleep.â Manuel rubbed his forehead
with the back of his fist.
âI thought maybe you were.â
âHowâs everything?â
âGood. How is everything with you?â
âNot so good.â
They were both silent. Zurito, the picador,
looked at Manuelâs white face. Manuel looked
down at the picadorâs enormous hands folding
the paper to put away in his pocket.
âI got a favor to ask you, Manos,â Manuel
said.
Manosduros was Zuritoâs nickname. He
never heard it without thinking of his huge
hands. He put them forward on the table
self-consciously.
âLetâs have a drink,â he said.
âSure,â said Manuel.
The waiter came and went and came again.
He went out of the room looking back at the
two men at the table.
âWhatâs the matter, Manolo?â Zurito set
down his glass.
âWould you pic two bulls for me to-morrow
night?â Manuel asked, looking up at Zurito
across the table.
âNo,â said Zurito. âIâm not pic-ing.â
Manuel looked down at his glass. He had
expected that answer; now he had it. Well, he
had it.
âIâm sorry, Manolo, but Iâm not pic-ing.â
Zurito looked at his hands.
âThatâs all right,â Manuel said.
âIâm too old,â Zurito said.
âI just asked you,â Manuel said.
âIs it the nocturnal to-morrow?â
âThatâs it. I figured if I had just one good
pic, I could get away with it.â
âHow much are you getting?â
âThree hundred pesetas.â
âI get more than that for pic-ing.â
âI know,â said Manuel. âI didnât have any
right to ask you.â
âWhat do you keep on doing it for?â Zurito
asked. âWhy donât you cut off your coleta,
Manolo?â
âI donât know,â Manuel said.
âYouâre pretty near as old as I am,â Zurito
said.
âI donât know,â Manuel said. âI got to do
it. If I can fix it so that I get an even break,
thatâs all I want. I got to stick with it, Manos.â
âNo, you donât.â
âYes, I do. Iâve tried keeping away from
it.â
âI know how you feel. But it isnât right.
You ought to get out and stay out.â
âI canât do it. Besides, Iâve been going good
lately.â
Zurito looked at his face.
âYouâve been in the hospital.â
âBut I was going great when I got hurt.â
Zurito said nothing. He tipped the cognac
out of his saucer into his glass.
âThe papers said they never saw a better
faena,â Manuel said.
Zurito looked at him.
âYou know when I get going Iâm good,â
Manuel said.
âYouâre too old,â the picador said.
âNo,â said Manuel. âYouâre ten years older
than I am.â
âWith me itâs different.â
âIâm not too old,â Manuel said.
They sat silent, Manuel watching the picadorâs
face.
âI was going great till I got hurt,â Manuel
offered.
âYou ought to have seen me, Manos,â Manuel
said, reproachfully.
âI donât want to see you,â Zurito said. âIt
makes me nervous.â
âYou havenât seen me lately.â
âIâve seen you plenty.â
Zurito looked at Manuel, avoiding his eyes.
âYou ought to quit it, Manolo.â
âI canât,â Manuel said. âIâm going good
now, I tell you.â
Zurito leaned forward, his hands on the table.
âListen. Iâll pic for you and if you donât go
big to-morrow night, youâll quit. See? Will
you do that?â
âSure.â
Zurito leaned back, relieved.
âYou got to quit,â he said. âNo monkey
business. You got to cut the coleta.â
âI wonât have to quit,â Manuel said. âYou
watch me. Iâve got the stuff.â
Zurito stood up. He felt tired from arguing.
âYou got to quit,â he said. âIâll cut your
coleta myself.â
âNo, you wonât,â Manuel said. âYou wonât
have a chance.â
Zurito called the waiter.
âCome on,â said Zurito. âCome on up to
the house.â
Manuel reached under the seat for his suitcase.
He was happy. He knew Zurito would
pic for him. He was the best picador living.
It was all simple now.
âCome on up to the house and weâll eat,â
Zurito said.
Manuel stood in the patio de caballos waiting
for the Charlie Chaplins to be over. Zurito
stood beside him. Where they stood it was
dark. The high door that led into the bull-ring
was shut. Above them they heard a shout,
then another shout of laughter. Then there
was silence. Manuel liked the smell of the
stables about the patio de caballos. It smelt
good in the dark. There was another roar from
the arena and then applause, prolonged applause,
going on and on.
âYou ever seen these fellows?â Zurito asked,
big and looming beside Manuel in the dark.
âNo,â Manuel said.
âTheyâre pretty funny.â Zurito said. He
smiled to himself in the dark.
The high, double, tight-fitting door into the
bull-ring swung open and Manuel saw the ring
in the hard light of the arc-lights, the plaza,
dark all the way around, rising high; around
the edge of the ring were running and bowing
two men dressed like tramps, followed by a
third in the uniform of a hotel bell-boy who
stooped and picked up the hats and canes thrown
down onto the sand and tossed them back up
into the darkness.
The electric light went on in the patio.
âIâll climb onto one of those ponies while
you collect the kids,â Zurito said.
Behind them came the jingle of the mules,
coming out to go into the arena and be hitched
onto the dead bull.
The members of the cuadrilla, who had been
watching the burlesque from the runway between
the barrera and the seats, came walking
back and stood in a group talking, under the
electric light in the patio. A good-looking lad
in a silver-and-orange suit came up to Manuel
and smiled.
âIâm Hernandez,â he said and put out his
hand.
Manuel shook it.
âTheyâre regular elephants weâve got to-night,â
the boy said cheerfully.
âTheyâre big ones with horns,â Manuel
agreed.
âYou drew the worst lot,â the boy said.
âThatâs all right,â Manuel said. âThe bigger
they are, the more meat for the poor.â
âWhere did you get that one?â Hernandez
grinned.
âThatâs an old one,â Manuel said. âYou
line up your cuadrilla, so I can see what Iâve
got.â
âYouâve got some good kids,â Hernandez
said. He was very cheerful. He had been on
twice before in nocturnals and was beginning
to get a following in Madrid. He was happy
the fight would start in a few minutes.
âWhere are the pics?â Manuel asked.
âTheyâre back in the corrals fighting about
who gets the beautiful horses,â Hernandez
grinned.
The mules came through the gate in a rush,
the whips snapping, bells jangling and the
young bull ploughing a furrow of sand.
They formed up for the paseo as soon as the
bull had gone through.
Manuel and Hernandez stood in front. The
youths of the cuadrillas were behind, their
heavy capes furled over their arms. In back,
the four picadors, mounted, holding their steel-tipped
push-poles erect in the half-dark of the
corral.
âItâs a wonder Retana wouldnât give us
enough light to see the horses by,â one picador
said.
âHe knows weâll be happier if we donât get
too good a look at these skins,â another pic answered.
âThis thing Iâm on barely keeps me off the
ground,â the first picador said.
âWell, theyâre horses.â
âSure, theyâre horses.â
They talked, sitting their gaunt horses in the
dark.
Zurito said nothing. He had the only steady
horse of the lot. He had tried him, wheeling
him in the corrals and he responded to the bit
and the spurs. He had taken the bandage off
his right eye and cut the strings where they had
tied his ears tight shut at the base. He was a
good, solid horse, solid on his legs. That was
all he needed. He intended to ride him all
through the corrida. He had already, since he
had mounted, sitting in the half-dark in the
big, quilted saddle, waiting for the paseo, pic-ed
through the whole corrida in his mind. The
other picadors went on talking on both sides of
him. He did not hear them.
The two matadors stood together in front of
their three peones, their capes furled over their
left arms in the same fashion. Manuel was
thinking about the three lads in back of him.
They were all three MadrileÃ±os, like Hernandez,
boys about nineteen. One of them, a
gypsy, serious, aloof, and dark-faced, he liked
the look of. He turned.
âWhatâs your name, kid?â he asked the
gypsy.
âFuentes,â the gypsy said.
âThatâs a good name,â Manuel said.
The gypsy smiled, showing his teeth.
âYou take the bull and give him a little run
when he comes out,â Manuel said.
âAll right,â the gypsy said. His face was
serious. He began to think about just what he
would do.
âHere she goes,â Manuel said to Hernandez.
âAll right. Weâll go.â
Heads up, swinging with the music, their
right arms swinging free, they stepped out,
crossing the sanded arena under the arc-lights,
the cuadrillas opening out behind, the picadors
riding after, behind came the bull-ring servants
and the jingling mules. The crowd applauded
Hernandez as they marched across the arena.
Arrogant, swinging, they looked straight ahead
as they marched.
They bowed before the president, and the
procession broke up into its component parts.
The bull-fighters went over to the barrera and
changed their heavy mantles for the light fighting
capes. The mules went out. The picadors
galloped jerkily around the ring, and two rode
out the gate they had come in by. The servants
swept the sand smooth.
Manuel drank a glass of water poured for
him by one of Retanaâs deputies, who was acting
as his manager and sword-handler. Hernandez
came over from speaking with his own manager.
âYou got a good hand, kid,â Manuel complimented
him.
âThey like me,â Hernandez said happily.
âHow did the paseo go?â Manuel asked
Retanaâs man.
